title: Chinese government granted blood bank equipment to National Blood Bank Network of Cuba
description: On 10 July, 2009, Ding Shan, the Chargé d’affaires of the Chinese Embassy in Cuba, and the Deputy Minister of Foreign Trade and Investment, Ramon Ripoll Dias, signed Letters of Exchange confirming the provision blood bank equipment to Cuba's National Blood Bank Network (Red Nacional de Bancos de Sangre).   This batch of blood bank equipment is the third batch provided by the Chinese government to Cuba and will be mainly used in remote mountainous areas in eastern Cuba. The batch will consist of biological safety cabinets, centrifuges, blood refrigeration equipment and mobile blood banks, and other necessary equipment.   On December 28, 2009, the equipment contract was signed by Yan Jingyao, vice president of the MEHECO Corporation, and Nancy Cruz, from Empresa Ejecutora de Donativos (EMED), the executor of donations in Cuba.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese government granted blood bank equipment to National Blood Bank Network of Cuba

# Description
On 10 July, 2009, Ding Shan, the Chargé d’affaires of the Chinese Embassy in Cuba, and the Deputy Minister of Foreign Trade and Investment, Ramon Ripoll Dias, signed Letters of Exchange confirming the provision blood bank equipment to Cuba's National Blood Bank Network (Red Nacional de Bancos de Sangre).   This batch of blood bank equipment is the third batch provided by the Chinese government to Cuba and will be mainly used in remote mountainous areas in eastern Cuba. The batch will consist of biological safety cabinets, centrifuges, blood refrigeration equipment and mobile blood banks, and other necessary equipment.   On December 28, 2009, the equipment contract was signed by Yan Jingyao, vice president of the MEHECO Corporation, and Nancy Cruz, from Empresa Ejecutora de Donativos (EMED), the executor of donations in Cuba.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of blood bank equipment for healthcare purposes, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates 34,527 metric tons of rice, 18,966 metric tons of wheat flour, and 60,334 metric tons of maize in 2009 (Linked to Project ID#63382, #63390)
description: In October 2009, when Premier Wen Jiabao visited North Korea, an agreement was reached in which the Chinese Government committed to donate 30,000 tons of food (captured via Project ID#63004), 50,000 tons of fuel oil (captured via Project ID#63382), and 80,000 tons of high-quality coal (captured via Project ID#63390) to the Government of North Korea. However, according to Chinese Government reporting to the World Food Program’s International Food Aid Information System (INTERFAIS), it ultimately donated 34,527 metric tons of rice (in seven separate deliveries of 2621 tons, 4022 tons, 6191 tons, 3474 tons, 6489 tons, 5311 tons, and 6419 tons), 18,966 metric tons of wheat flour (in six separate deliveries of 1248 tons, 928 tons, 1431 tons, 2942 tons, 1872 tons, 10545 tons), and 60,334 metric tons of maize (in six separate deliveries of 2670 tons, 1492 tons, 1574 tons, 15966 tons, 30884 tons, 7748 tons) to North Korea in 2009.   To estimate the monetary value of the rice donation ($21,242,736.75), AidData takes the international price of a ton of rice in January 2009 ($615.25) and multiplies it by 34,527 tons. To estimate the monetary value of the wheat donation ($4,006,946.82), AidData takes the international price of a ton of wheat in January 2009 ($211.27) and multiplies it by 18,966 tons. To estimate the monetary value of the maize donation ($10,455,278.86), AidData takes the international price of a ton of maize in January 2009 ($173.29) and multiplies it by 60,334 tons. The combined monetary value of these food aid donations is $35,704,962.43.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Government donates 34,527 metric tons of rice, 18,966 metric tons of wheat flour, and 60,334 metric tons of maize in 2009 (Linked to Project ID#63382, #63390)

# Description
In October 2009, when Premier Wen Jiabao visited North Korea, an agreement was reached in which the Chinese Government committed to donate 30,000 tons of food (captured via Project ID#63004), 50,000 tons of fuel oil (captured via Project ID#63382), and 80,000 tons of high-quality coal (captured via Project ID#63390) to the Government of North Korea. However, according to Chinese Government reporting to the World Food Program’s International Food Aid Information System (INTERFAIS), it ultimately donated 34,527 metric tons of rice (in seven separate deliveries of 2621 tons, 4022 tons, 6191 tons, 3474 tons, 6489 tons, 5311 tons, and 6419 tons), 18,966 metric tons of wheat flour (in six separate deliveries of 1248 tons, 928 tons, 1431 tons, 2942 tons, 1872 tons, 10545 tons), and 60,334 metric tons of maize (in six separate deliveries of 2670 tons, 1492 tons, 1574 tons, 15966 tons, 30884 tons, 7748 tons) to North Korea in 2009.   To estimate the monetary value of the rice donation ($21,242,736.75), AidData takes the international price of a ton of rice in January 2009 ($615.25) and multiplies it by 34,527 tons. To estimate the monetary value of the wheat donation ($4,006,946.82), AidData takes the international price of a ton of wheat in January 2009 ($211.27) and multiplies it by 18,966 tons. To estimate the monetary value of the maize donation ($10,455,278.86), AidData takes the international price of a ton of maize in January 2009 ($173.29) and multiplies it by 60,334 tons. The combined monetary value of these food aid donations is $35,704,962.43.
justification: Project involves food aid donations without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of rice, wheat flour, and maize for food security assistance

title: Chinese Government donates 50,000 tons of fuel oil in 2009 (Linked to Project ID#63004, #63390)
description: In October 2009, when Premier Wen Jiabao visited North Korea, an agreement was reached in which the Chinese Government committed to donate 30,000 tons of food (captured via Project ID#63004), 50,000 tons of fuel oil (captured via Project ID#63382), and 80,000 tons of high-quality coal (captured via Project ID#63390) to the Government of North Korea. It is unclear if and when this project was implemented.    50,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 365,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($22,611,750), AidData takes the average price ($61.95) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) Crude Oil in 2007 and multiplies it by 365,000 barrels of oil.

title: State Grid Corporation provides RMB 159 million for 630MW Shuifeng Hydropower Plant Renovation Project
description: In 2009, State Grid Corporation provided RMB 159 million ($25 million) of funding for the 630MW Shuifeng Hydropower Plant Renovation Project. The purpose of this project was to refurbish the Shuifeng Hydropower Station (also known as the Sup’ung Hydroelectric Power Station) on the Yalu River between Kuandian Manchu Autonomous County, Liaoning Province in China and Sakju County, North Pyongan Province in North Korea. China-Korea Hydropower Company (中朝水力发电公司) — a joint venture of the two governments established in 1955 — is responsible for the operations and maintenance of the Shuifeng Hydropower Plant. State Grid Corporation of China (SGCC) and Sinohydro Corporation Ltd were the contractors responsible for project implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on August 15, 2009. Then, on December 28, 2010, a planned explosion blasted apart a 273-meter back-up dam to Shuifeng hydropower station to support the renovation effort. The project was completed on June 22, 2011. Then, a formal project handover ceremony was held on June 28, 2011 and a project completion ceremony was held on August 30, 2012.   The Shuifeng (Sup’ung) dam is a 106 m (348 ft) tall and 899.5 m (2,951 ft) long concrete gravity dam with a crest elevation of 126.4 m (415 ft). The dam's spillway consists of 26 sluice gates with a maximum discharge capacity of 37,650 m3/s (1,329,597 cu ft/s). An auxiliary spillway 1.7 km (1 mi) north of the dam consists of 16 sluice gates and has a maximum discharge capacity of 17,046 m3/s (601,974 cu ft/s). The dam's reservoir has a capacity of 14,600,000,000 m3 (11,836,413 acre-ft) of which 7,900,000,000 m3 (6,404,634 acre⋅ft) is active (or "useful") for power generation. The dam sits at the head of a 52,912 km2 (20,429 sq mi) catchment area and its reservoir has a surface area of 274 km2 (106 sq mi). The original power station at the base of the dam contains six 105 MW Francis turbine-generators which are afforded an average hydraulic head of 77 m (253 ft). The additional power station on China's side contains two 67.5 MW Francis turbine generators. The total installed capacity of the dam's power stations is 765 MW.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Sup’ung Hydroelectric Power Station Upgrading Project, the Sup’ung Hydropower Plant Upgrading Project, the Shuifeng Dam Flood Control Facility Renovation Project, and the Flood Control Facilities Reconstruction Project of the Shuifeng Hydropower Station.  The Chinese project title is 鸭绿江水丰水电站改造工程 or 辽宁省丹东市水丰水电站的防洪设施改造工程. The Shuifeng Hydropower Station is known as 水豐水庫 (or 水丰水库) in Chinese and 수풍댐 in Korean2. The Shuifeng (Sup’ung) dam was constructed by the Japanese between 1937 and 1943 in order to generate electricity and it has been repaired and renovated multiple times — primarily due to spillway damage from flooding. Flooding in 1946 damaged the stilling basin at the toe of the dam and destroyed its spillway, requiring repairs the next year. Between September 1949 and April 1950, in a second repair, the spillway and plunge pool were renovated. Between 1955 and 1958, repairs were made to the dam and power station, which had suffered damages from plundering by the Soviet army and the Korean War. The generators removed by the Soviets were replaced and the installed capacity of the power station upgraded to 630 MW. In 1983, China began constructing an additional power station just downstream of the dam on their side of the river with two 67.5 MW generators. The first was commissioned in 1987 and the second in 1988.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title

# Description
In 2009, State Grid Corporation provided RMB 159 million ($25 million) of funding for the 630MW Shuifeng Hydropower Plant Renovation Project. The purpose of this project was to refurbish the Shuifeng Hydropower Station (also known as the Sup’ung Hydroelectric Power Station) on the Yalu River between Kuandian Manchu Autonomous County, Liaoning Province in China and Sakju County, North Pyongan Province in North Korea. State Grid Corporation of China (SGCC) and Sinohydro Corporation Ltd were the contractors responsible for project implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on August 15, 2009. Then, on December 28, 2010, a planned explosion blasted apart a 273-meter back-up dam to Shuifeng hydropower station to support the renovation effort. The project was completed on June 22, 2011. Then, a formal project handover ceremony was held on June 28, 2011 and a project completion ceremony was held on August 30, 2012.   The Shuifeng (Sup’ung) dam is a 106 m (348 ft) tall and 899.5 m (2,951 ft) long concrete gravity dam with a crest elevation of 126.4 m (415 ft). title: Chinese Government donates vehicles to China-DPRK Friendship Thaekam Cooperative Farm
description: On October 6, 2009, the Chinese Government donated vehicles to the China-DPRK Friendship Thaekam Cooperative Farm (中朝友谊宅庵合作农场).
staff_comments: The DPRK-China Friendship Thaekam Cooperative Farm was initially built with Chinese Government assistance in 1953. On February 19, 1958, Premier Zhou Enlai, accompanied by Chairman Kim Il Sung, visited the farm. To commemorate this visit, the North Korean side named the farm as the Korea-China Friendship House and Cooperative Farm on September 28, 1959.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government donates vehicles to China-DPRK Friendship Thaekam Cooperative Farm

# Description
On October 6, 2009, the Chinese Government donated vehicles to the China-DPRK Friendship Thaekam Cooperative Farm (中朝友谊宅庵合作农场).
justification: Vehicle donation to cooperative farm appears to be a social development initiative without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Vehicle donation to cooperative farm, no specific energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2009
description: In 2009, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($227,046,750), AidData has taken the average price ($61.95) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2009 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
staff_comments: 1. In 2012, a North Korean source disclosed that every year ‘the Ministry of Commerce of China and the North Korean government will discuss the catalogue of aid products, quantity, period, etc., but it is basically 100,000 tons of grain, 500,000 tons of oil, and materials needed by North Korea worth 20 million US dollars.’  This annual oil donation arrangement between the Chinese Government and the North Korean Government dates back to the 1970s. On October 17, 1970, the Chinese Government and the Government of North Korea signed an Agreement on Mutual Supply of Critical Materials 1971-1976. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide the North Korean Government with 500,000 tons of crude oil per year.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2009

# Description
In 2009, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($227,046,750), AidData has taken the average price ($61.95) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2009 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
justification: Project involves donation of crude oil and utilization of oil pipeline infrastructure, directly supporting fossil fuel dependency
evidence: 500,000 tons of crude oil donation, Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline infrastructure, processing at Ponghwa Chemical Factory

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 4 million grant for humanitarian aid to refugees in the DRC
description: On March 24, 2009, Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Zhai Jun delivered humanitarian aid for refugees in the DRC worth RMB 4 million. The handover agreement was signed between Zhai and his DR Congolese counterpart Ignace Gata Mavita. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), in 2009 the Chinese Government committed $58,586.60 of grant funding for a project called "Aide humanitaire urgente pour les réfugiés à l'Est de la RDC,” which was to take place in the Bas Uele, Haut Uele, Ituri, and Tshopo regions of the country. As of July 2019, $58,565.15 of grant funding had been disbursed in support of this project. It is likely that this AMP record refers to the same project. This project is completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 4 million grant for humanitarian aid to refugees in the DRC

# Description
On March 24, 2009, Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Zhai Jun delivered humanitarian aid for refugees in the DRC worth RMB 4 million. The handover agreement was signed between Zhai and his DR Congolese counterpart Ignace Gata Mavita. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), in 2009 the Chinese Government committed $58,586.60 of grant funding for a project called "Aide humanitaire urgente pour les réfugiés à l'Est de la RDC,” which was to take place in the Bas Uele, Haut Uele, Ituri, and Tshopo regions of the country. As of July 2019, $58,565.15 of grant funding had been disbursed in support of this project. It is likely that this AMP record refers to the same project. This project is completed.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and refugee support, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Humanitarian aid for refugees, grant funding for emergency response, social development focus

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Ngiri-Ngiri Primary School Construction Project (Linked to projects #19663 and #85305)
description: During an official visit in 2006, the Governor of Kinshasa secured a pledge from the Chinese Government for the construction of a new school to be built in Ngiri-Ngiri, Kinshasa. China Jiangsu Construction Development Company won the tender in consortium with the Chinese Engineering Company. Construction began in December 2009 and ended in November 2010. The school included six classrooms, private apartments, four offices, four toilets, a library, and a leisure hall. As of 2011, the school has about 16 teachers and 450 students, about 60% of which are girls.  The Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) reported a combined grant commitment amount of $2,196,997.436 for the Ngiri-Ngiri Primary School Construction Project and the Kisangani Primary Schools Construction Project (recorded in the linked project #19663). The grant commitment for both these projects is recorded in the umbrella project #85305. This project is completed. The French project title is Construction d'une école rurale à Kinshasa et deux à Kisangani.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Ngiri-Ngiri Primary School Construction Project (Linked to projects #19663 and #85305)

# Description
During an official visit in 2006, the Governor of Kinshasa secured a pledge from the Chinese Government for the construction of a new school to be built in Ngiri-Ngiri, Kinshasa. China Jiangsu Construction Development Company won the tender in consortium with the Chinese Engineering Company. Construction began in December 2009 and ended in November 2010. The school included six classrooms, private apartments, four offices, four toilets, a library, and a leisure hall. As of 2011, the school has about 16 teachers and 450 students, about 60% of which are girls.  The Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) reported a combined grant commitment amount of $2,196,997.436 for the Ngiri-Ngiri Primary School Construction Project and the Kisangani Primary Schools Construction Project (recorded in the linked project #19663). The grant commitment for both these projects is recorded in the umbrella project #85305. This project is completed. The French project title is Construction d'une école rurale à Kinshasa et deux à Kisangani.
justification: Project is focused on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of primary school with classrooms, offices, library, and leisure facilities

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Kisangani Primary Schools Construction Project (Linked to project #19114 and #85305)
description: In 2006, the Chinese Government pledged to build two rural schools in the eastern city of Kisangani. The Congolese authorities initially agreed to level the ground and provide electricity and water, but they had trouble doing so, and the Chinese Government signed an agreement in February 2009 to undertake these activities as well. Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on April 1, 2009, and ended on October 27, 2009. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government committed $2,196,997.436 of grant funding for the construction of these schools and for the construction of a school in Kinshasa (recorded in the linked project #19114). The AMP also indicates that the Chinese Government almost fully disbursed this amount in 2009, as $2,196,193.27 was disbursed. The funding for these projects is recorded in the umbrella project #85305.  The French project title is Construction d'une école rurale à Kinshasa et deux à Kisangani. The Chinese project title is 援刚果（金）两所农村小学校项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Kisangani Primary Schools Construction Project (Linked to project #19114 and #85305)

# Description
In 2006, the Chinese Government pledged to build two rural schools in the eastern city of Kisangani. The Congolese authorities initially agreed to level the ground and provide electricity and water, but they had trouble doing so, and the Chinese Government signed an agreement in February 2009 to undertake these activities as well. Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on April 1, 2009, and ended on October 27, 2009. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government committed $2,196,997.436 of grant funding for the construction of these schools and for the construction of a school in Kinshasa (recorded in the linked project #19114). The AMP also indicates that the Chinese Government almost fully disbursed this amount in 2009, as $2,196,193.27 was disbursed. The funding for these projects is recorded in the umbrella project #85305.  The French project title is Construction d'une école rurale à Kinshasa et deux à Kisangani. The Chinese project title is 援刚果（金）两所农村小学校项目.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of rural schools, education sector focus, no energy-related components mentioned
